Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Epidural Dexmedetomidine in Low-Concentration PCEA for Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Sixty patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists grade I to II undergoing TKA were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: Sixty patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists grade I to II undergoing TKA

Intervention.evidence: 0.125% bupivacaine + fentanyl 4 µg/mL (group R) or 0.1% bupivacaine + fentanyl 2 µg/mL with an epidural injection of dexmedetomidine 1 µg/kg (group D)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the impact of adding epidural dexmedetomidine to low-concentration patient-controlled epidural analgesia (PCEA) on pain control and side effects in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain control measured by the numeric pain rating scale (NRS) over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through concealed envelopes

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists grade I to II undergoing TKA were randomly assigned

Number_Analysed.evidence: Fifty-five patients were analysed per protocol

Result_Outcome.evidence: Both groups achieved similar pain control (NRS scores, p > 0.05). Group D had lower rates of urinary retention (28.6% vs. 59.3%, p = 0.022)

Harms.evidence: Group D had lower rates of urinary retention (28.6% vs. 59.3%, p = 0.022) and pruritus, while sedation was higher in group D in the recovery room.
